displayed_text: Patient: I’m so - I’ve seen it. I’ve seen it… Doctor: Okay. Yeah, this’ll be… Patient: …and I’ve had it so if that makes more sense for you… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: …go for it. Doctor: Thank you. I think you know when you have stuff in the in the belly though we don’t like to open you up unless we have to. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because it will create more scarring and that’s a different thing than the prostate. Patient: I had none from that da Vinci procedure. Doctor: We will, we will get in, we will get out with these samples, done. Now you know anytime we poke there’s always a downside because you’re poking… Patient: Sure. Doctor: …bleeding, infection, you could pop something, uh admission, any of the above. So… Patient: Mhmm.

Patient: Okay. Patient: Okay, is that early enough? Would that be early enough? Could that be early? Doctor: Would you like it? Patient: Oh yes, we’d like eight thirty? Doctor: You’d like that today. Okay. I will request; I’ll say eight a.m. if possible. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’ll request, I don't know if its available, but I hope it is; if it’s eight a.m., it will be earlier. Patient: That will be fine. Doctor: So that will be for the appointment itself. So we’ll sign that. And then the next step will be to order the PSA and the testosterone the week before Patient: Could you also include the um, my diabetes AC. Doctor: The A1C. Patient: Yes, A1C and I could just give them to my doctor.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: go running off somewhere. Okay, that sounds good Dr. H____, let’s do it. Patient: I mean that works for me. Doctor: Ok, that’s it. Patient: I mean since I got to come here anyway. Doctor: Yes and honestly I think your pain sometimes gets worse because you’re anemic Patient: Yeah, I mean it’s Doctor: so we got to fix that. Patient: it’s got to be worse since the last time I got that prescription from you. Doctor: Correct. Patient: It wasn’t as bad as it is now. Doctor: Right. Patient: Because I get to the bottom of the prescription it’s like…

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now we have seen folks you know stop the testosterone and PSA goes back down. Some of that elevation is related to, to stimulate production. Patient: Right. Doctor: So you know we’d like to see where, where we go with that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh in terms of once we reboot to be well again. The uh the problem we face is you know looking at the trials there are sort of two levels of looking at what’s available next. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Standard stuff. Trials. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So standard stuff, you’ve now had kind of the standard hormone treatments. Both of the two that we have. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Zytiga and Xtandi.

Family Member: Yeah guess the question I have is, what if for some reason the roads are really bad, the weather’s really bad? Are you flexible? Doctor: Oh, we would just reschedule. Oh, yes. We would never put you at risk for safety. If let's say you're just sick with something, it's not cancer related. Family Member: Right. Doctor: You don't come down. You got to do this hard thing. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Sometimes we have to be a little bit off cycle because, again, the weather for us is usually the big thing. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: But sometimes it's vacation and special events and life. Patient: . Right now. Family Member: Okay, what if he goes on chemo- Doctor: Uh huh. Family Member: How is his reaction or side effects kind of differ from the way they are right now.

Patient: Or when I would I brush my teeth. Doctor: Yep. Yep. So is it better now on the medicine? Patient: It’s gone. Family Member 1: So that might happen with this pill now, right? Or we don't know? Doctor: We don't know, anything is possible, but most of it is, you know, it's going to be very cyclical, right? Patient: Right. Doctor: Sort of like this is different than the Elida which is always in your system. You take it every day. The chemo is in your system, but it peaks, you know, kind of seven to 10 days. You're like, “yeah, I don’t feel so great. I'm not gonna run the marathon.” But then you kind of come down and you're like, “oh, okay, great. It's three weeks later, and I feel great right in time for me to give you the next treatment. Doctor: It’s the roller coaster that I'm not sure you're really looking forward to where you rise up again. But we're hoping that it's not as severe. You know, part of the goal for development of any new medicine is that you hope it's better than the current one. Patient: Okay. Family Member 1: What about sleeping? He’s having trouble sleeping right now? Doctor: No, do you think it has something to do with the steroids, Dexamethasone that you're taking? Because that kind of wakes people up. Patient: No. Ever since I've been on Erlida I've had trouble sleeping.

Patient: I’ve been having it, doctor, I’ve been disappointed though uh when I put, two weeks after I put in there do not let anyone come and pick up my medication if it’s not me. Why would you still let somebody pay but they said it was another girl cuz C____ the young lady that said I do know – Doctor: Mmm. Patient: - said no it wasn’t us. It must have been the girl somebody new but she was at the office where they explained that to her. Doctor: Alright so I’ll you a new script then. Patient: But anyway… Doctor: And you’re gonna get it filled at H____? Patient: Oh yeah but anyway, but anyway uh Dr. B____ the, the, the I think he’s short. I can’t think of his name. Anyway, he told me to talk to him. It’s a Chinese guy that that that denied me, but his boss… Doctor: M____ Pharmacy? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Or where? Patient: His boss is the short guy. That’s who I’m waiting to talk to. I’m hoping he’ll be here today so that when I leave here today I can talk to him. Doctor: Okay. So we’ll give you the script and then you go there first see if they are willing to. Patient: Tell me what’s going on Dr. B____. That’s what I want to know. What is the – this is the call they’re sending everything

Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Not that I saw in my notes that --- Family Member: Uh, uh. Doctor: So, January twenty fifth, it says Dr. S_. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You have a nurse visit. Patient: Yeah, that’s a hormone shot and a follow up. And, just before that, I’m supposed to do a three month PSA for him, so. Doctor: Okay. And then, you have another appointment with him in April. Patient: That’s correct. Doctor: Well. You gotta decide. I don’t think you need to see both of us. (Pause) Patient: Because you –

Patient: No. No. No. From south to north. Doctor: North. Yeah. Patient: So but it wasn’t that warm in Florida these last few weeks. Doctor: So, we, we’re on camera right now. (waves to camera) Patient: I guess so. Doctor: I hope you brought your Grammy material with you. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. My publicist is very on call. Doctor: Yeah. So anything new going on? Patient: No. I mean as far as how I feel. Doctor: How do you feel? Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: No new pains? No new issues urinating? Nothing else? Patient: No. I still wake up a couple of times a night you know and go but uh other than that I’m pretty active, play golf a couple of times a week. You know? Nothing slows me down.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I think she has to get it improved from you insurance company and then you could come back in a week or two and get it. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And then you’ll have a consult. Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: And then you’ll come back and see me a week after the first injection, I mean a month after the first injection. Patient: Okay. Doctor: At that time you could let us know if you want the twelve month implant or if you want to go with the three month shot. And then we do this for about two years or so and then we stop hormone therapy. By that time you’re done with radiation therapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then we wait and see what happens. Hopefully the PSA stays low. Family Member: But during that whole two years you don’t really know what’s going on because you can’t measure it accurately right?
DOC Because the hormone therapy is suppressing what’s there and killing off ninety nine percent of it, then maybe not that last one percent, maybe, maybe not, the radiation does that. So we’re giving you all that we got. Um hum. Um hum. We want it all. Okay. Um and leakage issue. I think he’s doing pretty good, but how long does that typically take?
DOC About another month or so. A lot of times people get better suddenly.

Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: and then we check you for a period of a year because we want to know. Same thing like the flu shot is only good for a finite time, right, like this much time is in it. Well, we know every year you have to re-up on that flu shot. We have no idea about this medicine. It’s a one and done. So, our patient’s sign up for, hey I wonder what’s going on in nine months or a year after the fact. So, we hope you participate in that because it’s important for us to know so that’s one treatment option. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: Now, after we do that, a month after that I rescan you again because by then it’s already about ten, twelve weeks that’s passed, almost three months, and then we see what the scans are when they’re done; if they’re worse, the same, or sort of the same. So, that’s all your two choices. Um, and if it’s not or if your PSA is now going whoa, it’s really up there, we normally then will say okay, we either got to commit to chemo Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: or pills. Now, chemo and pills are FDA approved. Kind of just like when you had the chemo before Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: FDA approved. We would do a different chemo. I wouldn’t repeat the same chemo but it’s a cousin drug so it’s still once every three weeks just like before. Okay, the pills are four pills a day every day. Patient: For the rest of your life? Doctor: Yeah, until it stops working, which at some point after a couple years it sort of poops out and stops working. So, we have studies there too. So, you got to say okay, what’s this study with the chemo. Well, you know in Oncology we love to combine stuff so the study is either the pill or chemo plus the pill. I know. So, it’s a win-win in the sense that you either get the pill get the pill that you were going to get anyways Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: or you actually get the double whammy and you get the pill and Patient: and the chemo.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Well I thought maybe you was gonna give me another twenty and ninety. That’s what I was asking. Doctor: Well the Percocet we cannot give more than hundred twenty. Patient: Right. I know, I’m talking about OxyContin. Doctor: Yeah this is a long acting so it’s good for twe- twelve hours. So you only can take it morning and evening. Patient: Right. So I get twelve and twelve; I’ll take it at twelve and then I’ll take it again at twelve midnight. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: When I’m laying down and going to sleep. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And this is… Doctor: This is the sleeping pill, the Restoril. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Is that a (Pause35sec) Doctor: And your CAT scan (Pause15sec) Patient: Right. Doctor: They don’t really saw anything in your organs, your liver, all that looks good. Patient: Ah, okay. Doctor: And your bone scan (Pause6sec) Patient: Uh. Clinical study? (Pause5sec) Patient: My one meds is I wasn’t so sure that I could take. Doctor: So, yeah, when we saw you, you already had Abiraterone, enzaluta – Radium, docetaxel. And, so what we do next, uh, you know, the only thing you haven’t had is, uh, chemotherapy. Uh, another chemotherapy called Radia, uh – Jevtana, cabazitaxel would be standard treatment you could go through, and we were waiting because again, you’d finished your chemo – um, and uh Patient: Gotcha. Doctor: Um. So, uh. Patient: The enzalutamide. I, I don’t remember being on that.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Homemaker: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Homemaker

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: So we know still it’s invisible somewhere, so we can target what we can see. And we can still deal with you know what we can’t see. If that’s the combination of your thinking in terms of correct or that is a possibility? Doctor: I’m thinking that in terms of the sequence if you get the radiotherapy first. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That does not close the door to getting hormone therapy down the line. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: You start with the hormone therapy, the other option is going to disappear very quickly. And a radiation oncologist is not going to know what to target. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It would be very different if the spot was in the bone. Bone metastasis takes a very long time to disappear. Sometimes you know a small one can take up to a year to disappear. So oftentimes when a cancer is involved, when they start the hormone therapy about three months later, a week later, two weeks later you talk to the radiation oncologist and by the time he starts the radiation planning which might be six to eight weeks later, the spot is still where he can see it, he can zap it and target that. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And with a lymph node, uh if we start the hormone therapy even like a couple of weeks before that thing’s going to disappear; he won’t know what he’s targeting. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So all I’m saying is in theory that-

Patient: That gives me goose bumps. They never show up because my skin’s changed. Doctor: Yeah so here you go. (Laughs) Patient: Alright I’m gonna shut up and just let you keep talking. Doctor: Yeah well you know you need more chemo. That’s really what you need (laughs) Patient: I do? Doctor: You do. How ‘bout that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But your insurance today is not playing nice and it’s not letting us treat you today. Family Member: What? Doctor: Uh huh. Yes. K__’s yelling at somebody on the phone. United Health Care is not being very nice to you right now. And you know we put this in I don’t know how long ago right since the last time I’d seen you. They have hemmed and hawed and hemmed and hawed and given all sorts of problems. Patient: What do I need to do? Doctor: I don’t know. Patient: Can I do anything. I mean…
